Editor’s choice paper Mesoporous silica-immobilized FeCl3 as a highly efficient and recyclable catalyst for the nitration of benzene with NO2 to nitrobenzene Shenghui Zhou a Kuiyi You a b ⁎ Hongxu Gao a Renjie Deng a Fangfang Zhao a Pingle Liu a b Qiuhong Ai a b He’an Luo a b ⁎ a School of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, PR China School of Chemical Engineering Xiangtan University Xiangtan 411105 PR China b National & Local United Engineering Research Center for Chemical Process Simulation and Intensification, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, PR China National & Local United Engineering Research Center for Chemical Process Simulation and Intensification Xiangtan University Xiangtan 411105 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: School of Chemical Engineering, Xiangtan University, Xiangtan 411105, PR China. Graphical abstract Mesoporous silica-immobilized FeCl3 (FeCl3-SiO2) as a highly efficient and reusable catalyst for the nitration of benzene with NO2 has been successfully prepared in this work. The physical-chemical properties of samples were characterized by BET, XRD, TG-DTG, NH3-TPD, FT-IR, UV–vis DRS, Raman spectra and SEM. The characterization results indicated that FeCl3 could be immobilized on the silica surface by bonding of FeCl3 and silicon hydroxyl groups (SiOH) in forming the new Lewis acid sites of SiOFeCl2. The results showed the immobilized 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance (99% of benzene conversion with 99% of selectivity to nitrobenzene) under the optimized reaction conditions. Furthermore, the durability of catalyst was remarkably improved by immobilizing. The present immobilized FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst as a solid heterogeneous and stable catalyst could be conveniently recycled from the reaction media by filtering and remained highly catalytic performance even after five runs of recycling. The possible reaction pathway for the nitration of benzene with NO2 over FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst was suggested. This method provides a promising strategy for highly efficient preparation of nitro aromatic compounds by using NO2 as nitration reagent, with the potential industrial applications. Keywords Nitrobenzene Nitrogen dioxide FeCl3-SiO2 Immobilization Catalytic nitration 1 Introduction The aromatic nitration is one of the most important electrophilic substitution reactions in commercial manufacturing of various nitro aromatic compounds [1]. The nitrated aromatic compounds are extensively used as versatile organic intermediates. For instance, nitrobenzenes as important chemical raw material are widely utilized in the manufacture of aniline, dyes, explosives, medicines, agrochemicals, and the like [2]. The traditional industrial-scale nitration procedure of aromatic compounds employs a mixture of nitric acids and sulfuric acids [3,4]. Nevertheless, the mixed acid system not only displays poor regioselectivity for desired products, but also it leads to notorious facilities corrosion problem and yields large amounts of dilute sulphuric acid, which inevitably resulting in a high cost of recovery and generating environmental hazards [5]. Therefore, there is a drive to develop a new environmentally friendly nitration methodology avoiding sulfuric acid for the preparation of aromatics in the chemical industry [6]. In recent years, alternative solid acid catalysts are widely used to replace sulfuric acid due to easy separation from product, convenience for recycling, and environmental friendliness [7–9]. For example, several solid acid catalysts such as zeolite [10,11], H3PO4/MoO3/SiO2 [12], WO3/SiO2 [13], HPW/MCM-41 [14], H2SO4/SiO2 [15], and ion-exchange resin [16] have been studied to attempt to overcome the above-mentioned drawbacks. In the past few decades, Lewis acid catalysts have been extensively used in several acid catalyzed reactions since the catalyst is inexpensive and effective [17,18]. However, the conventional Lewis acid catalysts suffer from several major disadvantages associated with notorious difficulty in catalyst separation and recovery from the reaction mixture due to dissolution in reactant and product, serious corrosion of industrial equipment, and inevitable generation of high hazardous pollutions [18–20]. In order to overcome these problems, the research of immobilizing lewis acid on a support has arousing extensive attention due to environmental friendly, practical and economical concerns [18,21]. Currently, mesoporous materials such as SiO2 [22], Al2O3 [23], MCM-41 [24], SBA-15 [25] and montmorillonite [26] have been widely used as a carrier due to their appropriate pore structure and surface area. Among these supports, inexpensive silica acts as an excellent carrier with a large number of silicon hydroxyl groups on its surface which can electrostaticly interact with the metal chlorides resulting in firmly immobilization between them [22,27]. However, few investigations on nitration reaction using immobilized metal chlorides as catalysts have been reported so far. Thus, an exploratory research on immobilizing metal chlorides catalyst on a support for the nitration reaction in enhancing the stability of the catalyst and reducing the negative environmental effects is worthy of academic pursuit. In terms of nitrating agent, there are a lot of various new clean acid-free nitration agents such as N2O5 [28], nitrate salts [29], Zn(NO3)2·2N2O4 [30] and nitronium tetrafluoroborate [31] as an alternative of nitric acids have been used in nitration process over the years. Very efficient as these procedures for aromatic nitration are, high manufacture cost of nitrating agent, complicated synthetic process and generation of potential toxic wastes limit the use of these methods for industrialization. In recent years, nitrogen dioxide (NO2) acted as a non-acidic nitration agent for the aromatic nitration has received a great deal of attention [32]. It is universally acknowledged that the industrial nitric acid is manufactured from lower nitrogen oxides via a multi-step process. Therefore, NO2 can be regarded as a clean nitration agent to replace the traditional nitric acid in aromatic nitration [2,33,34], especially in large scale production. First, acid-free reaction process is safe and noncorrosive for production equipment. Second, NO2 as a mild nitrating agent can minimize the over-nitration and oxidation side products. Third, the costs of manufacturing nitric acid can be saved. Herein, we report the immobilized FeCl3-SiO2 as a efficient and sustainable catalyst for the nitration of benzene to nitrobenzene with NO2 as nitrating agent. The obtained results will be presented in detail in this paper. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and instruments Benzene (AR) and NO2 (purity >99.9%) were purchased from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Co., Ltd., China. and Beijing Chemical Co., Ltd., China, respectively. Anhydrous FeCl3, AlCl3, ZnCl2 were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Mesoporous silica gel (100mesh) was obtained commercially. Gas chromatography (GC) was performed on a Shimadzu GC-2010 Plus equipped with hydrogen flame ion detector (FID) and an RTX-5 column (30m×0.25mm×0.25um) for quantitative analysis by using internal standard method. Gas chromatography–Mass spectrometry (GC–MS) was run on a Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 Plus for qualitative analysis of products. 2.2 Catalyst preparation First, anhydrous FeCl3 with specific amount (0.16g, 0.53g, 1g) was quickly solubilized in 20mL anhydrous ethanol avoiding deliquescence before the dried SiO2 support (3g) was impregnated into the solution. The suspension was vigorously stirred and refluxed in N2 atmosphere at 80°C for 4h. After that, the solvent was then rotary evaporated at 60°C under vacuum before the dried yellowish powder was obtained. Finally, the samples were activated at 300°C in N2 atmosphere for 4h to give a black brownish powder. The resulting catalysts were sealed and then stored in a desiccator. The catalysts impregnated with 0.16g, 0.53g and 1g of FeCl3 were marked as 5%FeCl3-SiO2, 15%FeCl3-SiO2 and 25%FeCl3-SiO2 (wt%). 2.3 Catalytic nitration of benzene to nitrobenzene with NO2 The liquid phase nitration of benzene with NO2 was performed in a Teflon-lined 100mL reaction autoclave fitted with temperature-controlling device and magnetic stirrer. First, a certain amount of catalyst, benzene and cold liquid NO2 (<5°C) were charged to the stainless steel reaction autoclave in turn, and quickly sealing the reactor. Then the autoclave was submerged in an oil bath and heated to the required temperature. The reaction mixture was stirred at 100°C for 1h. When the reaction was finished and cooled to room temperature, the catalyst was separated and recovered by filtration. The resulting products were identified by GC–MS and quantitatively analyzed by GC using chlorobenzene as internal standard substance. The conversion of benzene and selectivity of nitrobenzene was calculated using the following formulas (Eqs. (1) and (2)). (1) C o n v e r s i o n o f b e n z e n e ( % ) = [ t h e a m o u n t ( m o l ) o f s t a r t i n g b e n z e n e ] − [ t h e a m o u n t ( m o l ) o f b e n z e n e r e cov e r e d ] t h e a m o u n t ( m o l ) o f s t a r t i n g b e n z e n e × 100 % (2) S e l e c t i v i t y o f n i t r o b e n z e n e ( % ) = t h e a m o u n t ( m o l ) o f n i t r o b e n z e n e [ t h e a m o u n t ( m o l ) o f s t a r t i n g b e n z e n e ] − [ t h e a m o u n t ( m o l ) o f b e n z e n e r e cov e r e d ] × 100 % 2.4 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) of the catalysts were carried out on a Japan Rigaku D-Max-2550VB+ 18kW X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.15418nm) at voltage and current of 40kV and 20mA. The textural properties of the samples were acquired on a Quantachrome Instruments NOVA 1000e analyzer by N2 adsorption at −70°C using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method for calculation. Thermogravimetric-derivative thermogravimetric (TG-DTG) analysis was performed by using a Mettler TGA-DSC1-1600HT thermogravimetric analyzer under 40mL/min N2 with a heating rate of 10°C/min from 30 to 700°C. The ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV–vis DRS) were recorded on an UV-2550 spectrophotometry with a scan range of 200–800nm using BaSO4 as background standard. The temperature programmed desorption with ammonia (NH3-TPD) was performed with 10vol% NH3 in Ar (30mLmin−1) from 100 to 500°C at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 in a CHEMBET-3000 instrument. Pyridine adsorbed FT-IR of the samples were recorded on a Nicolet380 instrument using KBr pellets in the range of 400–4000cm−1 to distinguish the nature of the acid sites. Raman spectra for the samples were collected on a Renishaw Raman spectrometer using a 514.5nm laser as the excitation source. The morphology of the samples was examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on a JSM-6610LV spectrometer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 N2 adsorption-desorption The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of SiO2 and FeCl3-SiO2 catalysts with different loadings are shown in Fig. 1 (A). The BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of SiO2 and FeCl3-SiO2 catalysts with different loadings are also summarized in Table 1 . It can be seen that the all samples exhibit similar Type IV isotherms with a hysteresis loops of type H1 as classified by IUPAC [35], indicating the mesoporous structures [36] are still maintained after the immobilization of FeCl3. However, the capillary condensation steps at P/Po =0.6–0.9 become less obvious from Fig. 1(A) after the incorporation of FeCl3. The pore size distribution obtained from the N2-desorption curves using the BJH method reveal that the pore volumes are decreased with increasing of FeCl3 loading, as shown in Fig. 1(B). In addition, the BET surface areas and pore volumes of FeCl3-SiO2 samples are gradually decreased with the elevated FeCl3 loading, while the pore diameter hardly changes. These results indicate that FeCl3 has been immobilized on the surface and pore channels of mesoporous silica. 3.1.2 XRD The XRD patterns of SiO2 and FeCl3-SiO2 catalysts with different loadings are shown in Fig. 2 . According to the XRD patterns, the mesoporous silica exhibits a characteristic broad diffraction peak at 2θ=22°. The intensity of characteristic peak of SiO2 is slightly weakened as FeCl3 is introduced to the mesoporous silica, which shows that the FeCl3 particles have entered to the support framework resulting in a decrease in the unordered mesoporous phase. Furthermore, the crystalline phase of FeCl3 is hardly observed in both 5%FeCl3-SiO2 and 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst, indicating FeCl3 has been highly dispersed and immobilized on the surface of SiO2 [22,37]. However, the 25% FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst shows obvious characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ=11.12°, 15.90°, 20.69°, 32.33°, and 35.54° corresponding to FeCl3 phase, which demonstrate that there are some non-immobilized FeCl3 particles on the surface of mesoporous silica. 3.1.3 TG-DTG The thermo-stability of SiO2 and FeCl3-SiO2 catalysts with different loadings in the temperature range 30–700°C was studied by TG-DTG, and the results are illustrated in Fig. 3 . Obviously, for the SiO2, only a mass loss stage (ca 5%) at temperatures ranging from 30 to 100°C is observed, which is assigned to the desorption of physisorbed water. However, the total mass loss percentage for 5%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst and 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst are almost similar to pure SiO2 (ca 3–5%) and the decomposition or sublimation peaks of FeCl3 cannot be observed. This results indicate that FeCl3 can be firmly immobilized on the surface of SiO2 by forming the stronger bond of SiOFeCl2. However, 25%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst shows obvious three weight loss peaks from 60°C to 400°C from the TG-DTG curves and the total mass loss percentage is ca 11% in Fig. 3, which shows that 25%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst is overloaded and the unbound FeCl3 on the surface of SiO2 results in continuously mass loss due to sequential decomposition and sublimation of FeCl3. These results demonstrate that the thermo-stability of FeCl3 is enhanced after the immobilization on the mesoporous silica. 3.1.4 NH3-TPD Fig. 4 (A) shows the NH3-TPD profiles for SiO2 and FeCl3-SiO2 samples with different loadings. All samples exhibit a NH3 desorption peak at around 150–200°C, which is attributed to the desorption of bonded ammonia on weak acid centers [38,39]. SiO2 shows the lowest acidity at comparatively lower temperature, indicating the mesoporous silica only has few weaker acid sites. It is interested that, the acidity of samples is remarkably improved as FeCl3 is immobilized on SiO2, and the acid strength as well as the number of acid sites is increased with the elevated FeCl3 loadings. Based on the measurements, maximum number of acid sites as well as the highest acid strength are observed in 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst. Furthermore, a peak at higher temperatures (between 330 and 400°C) related to moderate strength acid sites appears from the curves of 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst. This may be attributed to the adsorbed ammonia on the acid sites created by the interaction between Fe species and the Brönsted acid sites [40,41]. However, the acid amount of 25%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst shows the decreased trend. The possible reason is that the non-immobilized FeCl3 is aggregated on the SiO2 surface, which covers the acid sites and leads to decreasing acid amount and acid strength. These results indicate that 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst exhibits a suitable acid amount and acid strength. 3.1.5 Pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectra In order to obtain the information on the Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites of catalyst, the nature of acid sites of SiO2 and 15%FeCl3-SiO2 samples was confirmed by the pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectra, and the achieved results are depicted in Fig. 4(B). Obviously, the sole SiO2 shows little acidity as a result of the absence of IR peaks at 1650–1400cm−1. While FeCl3 is introduced to mesoporous silica, four characteristic peaks appear at 1450, 1490, 1540 and 1610cm−1. The band appeared at 1450 and 1610cm−1 is attributed to the characteristics of adsorbed pyridine on strong Lewis acidic centers [42,43], the band appeared at 1540cm−1 is assigned to the adsorbed pyridine on Brønsted acidic sites with the formation of pyridinum ions [44,45] and the band appeared at 1490cm−1 is the interaction of pyridine via the nitrogen lone-pair electrons with both Lewis and Brönsted acid sites [46]. These results indicate that the immobilized 15%FeCl3-SiO2 possesses both Lewis and Brönsted acid sites. 3.1.6 UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy The UV–vis DRS spectra of SiO2, FeCl3 and FeCl3-SiO2 catalysts are depicted in Fig. 5 (A). It is clearly seen that the pure SiO2 has no distinct electronic absorption band in the 200–750nm regions. In the UV–vis spectra of FeCl3-SiO2 catalysts with different loadings, there is evident UV–vis absorption band at 350nm, which can be assigned to absorbance for Fe species incorporated into the prepared catalysts [47]. Other absorption bands are similar to the spectrum of FeCl3. Furthermore, the absorption intensity of ultraviolet diffuse reflection is obviously enhanced as FeCl3 is introduced to mesoporous silica. These results indicate that FeCl3 is successfully immobilized on the supporter surface. 3.1.7 Raman spectroscopy Fig. 5(B) shows the major structural information concerning the surface FeCl3 species derived from the Raman spectroscopy. Two intense Raman bands at 188 and 332cm−1 can be attributed to deformation and bending mode of FeCl stretching vibrations in crystalline FeCl3 [48,49]. Similar peaks are observed in the 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst with a slightly red-shift of 30cm−1 and blue-shift of 45cm−1. The possible reason is that the strongly bonding interaction occurs between FeCl3 and SiO2 [49]. The characteristic Raman spectra further confirm that FeCl3 is firmly immobilized on the SiO2 surface. 3.1.8 SEM The surface morphology of SiO2 and FeCl3-SiO2 samples with different loadings was studied by SEM and the typical micrographs are showed in Fig. 6 . As can be seen, the amount of FeCl3 on the surface of mesoporous silica is gradually increased with the elevated loading. The surface of spherical SiO2 are relatively smooth and no obvious particles can be observed. After the immobilization treatment, the surface of the as-formed catalysts are rough compared with pure SiO2, indicating that the FeCl3 particles present on the mesoporous silica (Fig. 6(b)–(d)). However, a large amount of FeCl3 species can be observed on the surface of FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst when the loading of FeCl3 is increased to 25% (Fig. 6(d)). These results indicate that the FeCl3 particles are well immobilized on the mesoporous silica. 3.2 Effects of various catalysts on nitration reaction In an effort to evolve the best catalyst, several typical catalysts were screened under identical reaction conditions in the nitration of benzene, and the obtained results were summarized in Table 2 . In fact, nitrobenzene could be formed from benzene with NO2 in the absence of any catalysts, and only 25.8% of benzene conversion with 95.7% of selectivity to nitrobenzene was achieved. The benzene conversion and selectivity to nitrobenzene were improved in different degrees as the Brönsted acid catalysts (HY zeolite, HPW, SO4 2−/WO3) was introduced to this nitration system, and solid super acid SO4 2−/WO3 gave the higher benzene conversion (41.2%) and selectivity to nitrobenzene (98.0%). In addition, we performed some typical lewis acid catalysts, such as FeCl3, AlCl3, and ZnCl2 to catalyze this nitration reaction. To our delight, FeCl3 exhibited good catalytic performance, and 67.4% of benzene conversion and 99.1% of selectivity to nitrobenzene were obtained. The difference on the activity improvement for different lewis acids can be explained by the difference of electronegativities of metal cations. Fe3+ ions have relatively larger electronegativity values (12.6), compared with those of Al3+ (10.2) and Zn2+ ions (9.5). The larger value means the higher driving force to shift the disproportionation of dinitrogen tetroxide (N2O4) coordinated to the Lewis acid, thus exhibiting a stronger catalytic performance [26]. In addition, compared to the reaction without any catalyst, benzene conversion were hardly changed over SiO2, which showed that the supporter SiO2 had very little catalytic activity in the nitration of benzene with NO2. Interestingly, compared with the non-immobilized FeCl3 catalyst at the same amount of FeCl3, the benzene conversion was further enhanced over the immobilized FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst. This could be explained by the well-dispersed FeCl3 particles on SiO2 contributing to the full exposure of active sites. Among these immobilized FeCl3-SiO2 catalysts, 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst gave good results with 73.2% of benzene conversion and 99.2% of selectivity to nitrobenzene. 3.3 Optimization of reaction conditions Table 3 summarizes the representative results for the nitration reaction over 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst under the different conditions. Firstly, the effects of the reaction temperature on the conversion of benzene and selectivity to nitrobenzene were examined, as shown in Table 3(A). The conversion of benzene rapidly increased from 20.4% to 73.2% and the selectivity to nitrobenzene was maintained above 99% with the raised reaction temperature from 60°C to 100°C. However, the conversion increased relatively slowly with further increased reaction temperature (120°C), while the selectivity to nitrobenzene decreased quickly to 96.6%. The possible reason is that the higher reaction temperature accelerated the side reaction from nitrobenzene to dinitrobenzene. The products meta-dinitrobenzene and para-dinitrobenzene were detected in present experimental conditions. These results indicated that the reaction temperature is a significant factor to regulate the benzene conversion and selectivity to nitrobenzene. At the present reaction conditions, the suitable temperature was selected at 100°C. The effects of different molar ratios of benzene to NO2 on the nitration reaction are showed in Table 3(B). It can be seen that the conversion of benzene increases rapidly with the elevated concentration of NO2. The benzene conversion gradually increases from 55.3% to 73.2% with the molar ratio from 1:3 to 1:5, while the selectivity to nitrobenzene still remained at 99%. Further reducing the molar ratio to 1:7 led to a little increase in the conversion with obvious decrease in the selectivity to nitrobenzene (97.2%) due to the formation of dinitrobenzene. These results demonstrate that too high concentration of NO2 is not good for the selectivity to aim product. From the viewpoint of conversion and selectivity, the reasonable molar ratio of benzene to NO2 is 1:5. Finally, the experimental results for the nitration of benzene with different amount of catalyst are listed in Table 3(C). Obviously, with the elevated amount of catalyst from 0.2 to 0.4g, the conversion of benzene increased gradually from 73.2% to 98.7%, and the selectivity to nitrobenzene hardly changed. Therefore, from the single-factor experiment results, the appropriate reaction conditions is obtained that reaction temperature is 100°C, the molar ratio of benzene (0.03mol) to NO2 is 1:5, and the amount of 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst is 0.4g in the liquid-phase nitration of benzene. 3.4 The reusability of immobilized 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst and non-immobilized FeCl3 catalyst The recycle of immobilized 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst and non-immobilized FeCl3 catalyst in the nitration of benzene with NO2 was examined. After each reaction, the catalysts were separated by filtration and then used for the next turn without any other treatment under the same conditions. The reuse results of catalysts in the five runs were shown in Fig. 7 . It is clearly seen that the immobilized 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst exhibits excellent reusability and stability in this nitration reaction, and the benzene conversion and selectivity to nitrobenzene were basically maintained at 97% and 99% after five runs, respectively. However, the non-immobilized FeCl3 catalyst suffers from sharp decrease in the benzene conversion due to the dissolution in reaction system and the combination with water. These results demonstrate that the reusability and stability of catalyst is remarkably improved after the immobilization of FeCl3 and the 15%FeCl3-SiO2 can be used as an efficient and recyclable catalyst in the nitration of benzene with NO2. 3.5 The plausible catalytic reaction pathway for the nitration of benzene with NO2 over FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst Generally, NO2 has long been regarded as an equilibrium mixture between liquid N2O4 and NO2, and the dimer predominates at low temperatures or high pressure in the liquid form [50,51]. Heterolytic ionic disproportionation of dimeric NO2 (radical) to [NO+][NO3 −] always happens [52]. Therefore, on the basis of these results in this work, the similar reaction pathway for the catalytic nitration of benzene with NO2 over FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst is suggested in Fig. 8 . Firstly, Fe(III) which possesses high electronegativity values and is high electron-deficiency attracted electrons from dinitrogen tetroxide, then generating the higher driving force to promote the heterolytic disproportionation of dinitrogen tetroxide to [NO+][NO3 −] [52,53], resulting in the formation of an reactive species [(-Si-O-FeCl2)NO3 −][NO+] under the action of FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst. As a result, this active species reacted with an aromatic ring to produce a aromatic cation radical and rapidly release the reduced product NO at the same time [17]. Then, the aromatic cation radical reacted with NO2 and ultimately collapsed into nitration product nitrobenzene by deprotonation [54]. Meanwhile, the FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst was recovered by releasing nitric acid (HNO3) under the action of H+. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the immobilized FeCl3-SiO2 catalysts had been prepared successfully by bonding of FeCl3 and silicon hydroxyl groups (SiOH) in forming the new Lewis acid sites of SiOFeCl2, and their physical-chemical properties were characterized in this work. The results showed that the immobilized 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst as an efficient and recyclable catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance, and 99% of benzene conversion with 99% of selectivity to nitrobenzene was obtained under mild reaction conditions. The present catalyst could be conveniently separated from the reaction media and was proven to be stable and recyclable without considerable decrease in activity and selectivity after five cycles. The possible reaction pathway for the nitration of benzene with NO2 over FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst had been suggested based on the obtained experimental results. The developed 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst offers a promising and environmentally friendly alternative for the conventional homogeneous catalysts and possesses a potential for industrial applications in the production of nitro aromatic compounds. coredata.dc:description: Mesoporous silica-immobilized FeCl3 (FeCl3-SiO2) as a highly efficient and reusable catalyst for the nitration of benzene with NO2 has been successfully prepared in this work. The physical-chemical properties of samples were characterized by BET, XRD, TG-DTG, NH3-TPD, FT-IR, UV–vis DRS, Raman spectra and SEM. The characterization results indicated that FeCl3 could be immobilized on the silica surface by bonding of FeCl3 and silicon hydroxyl groups (SiOH) in forming the new Lewis acid sites of SiOFeCl2. The results showed the immobilized 15%FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance (99% of benzene conversion with 99% of selectivity to nitrobenzene) under the optimized reaction conditions. Furthermore, the durability of catalyst was remarkably improved by immobilizing. The present immobilized FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst as a solid heterogeneous and stable catalyst could be conveniently recycled from the reaction media by filtering and remained highly catalytic performance even after five runs of recycling. The possible reaction pathway for the nitration of benzene with NO2 over FeCl3-SiO2 catalyst was suggested. This method provides a promising strategy for highly efficient preparation of nitro aromatic compounds by using NO2 as nitration reagent, with the potential industrial applications.
coredata.dc:title: Mesoporous silica-immobilized FeCl3 as a highly efficient and recyclable catalyst for the nitration of benzene with NO2 to nitrobenzene
